name: 20% Off Local Beer- One Day Only

description:
August 9–October 30, 2016
Corridor Gallery

Artist and poet Ann Holmes first encountered Japanese folk ceramics while living in Tokyo in the late 1960s. Fascinated by the simple aesthetic, the craftsmanship, and the makers’ unassuming personalities and ways of life, Holmes visited many kiln towns to photograph and interview the artists and collect ceramic wares of various shapes and techniques. She donated a significant portion of her collection to UMMA in 2013.

Richly introduced in this presentation are works by ceramic artists emerging in the late 1960s and the early 1970s in the town of Mashiko, two hours north of Tokyo by train. Mashiko became an international mecca of folk ceramics after Hamada Shōji (1894–1978), a major figure of Japan’s Folk Craft (Mingei) Movement, set up his studio there in 1930. Hamada’s idea of ceramic making for a new age, which combined the aesthetic of folk ceramics and the modern concept of the studio artist, attracted many younger artists of unconventional backgrounds, including women.
name: In Focus: Modern Japanese Folk Ceramics

description:
Unwind from the workweek and flex your creative muscles while enjoying our exclusive Pointless craft beers. 

We will provide the writing and drawing prompts, doodle starters, colored pencils and markers, you provide your awesome self and your desire to relax and have fun.

Fridays, 3-7pm at Pointless Brewery & Theatre. 3014 Packard Road, Ann Arbor.
name: Drink & Draw / Imbibe & Inscribe

description:
Bring your well-worn items that could use a tune up, and we'll take a look at them! 

Or, make someone else's day by volunteering at Fix-It Friday and repairing their items.

Fix-It Friday:
Think of this as the last chance before you get rid of something; Free, but no Guarantee.

We will:
- try to diagnose what is wrong
- tell you if we think we may be able to fix it today
- tell you if you'll need a part, and where you might be able to get it
- try to fix it to the best of our ability, but in the limited time we have

However, we may not be able to fix it. Many products are not designed to be fixed, and just opening them up may damage them. Furthermore, we may not have someone on hand with the expertise to do a proper repair. Also, it may require a special part, tools, information, or materials to repair, or it may just require more time than we have.

We may end up damaging your item even more. Please let the repairer know how comfortable you are at each stage of diagnosis and repair.

Items that are often easier to repair: lamps, types of toys, broken wires, things that need epoxy/wood glue

Items that are often very difficult to repair: consumer electronics such as CD/Cassette boom boxes, TVs, radios, CD players, VCRs, and DVD players
name: August Fix-It Friday

description:
Join us on Friday, August 19, from 6:00 PM to 9:00 PM for the opening reception of Ultimate Stars—a pop-up exhibition curated by Doug Coombe—with live music from DJs Chuck Sipperley and Michael Dykehouse, along with a live shadow puppet performance by Patrick Elkins and portriats by Jim Cherewick. Ultimate Stars is a two-week showcase of local artists who explore creativity through visual art and music.

This event is FREE and open to the public. 

About Doug Coombe: 

Doug Coombe is— an Ann Arbor and Detroit based music/editorial photographer; documenter of the world's best music scene for 20 years; photographer for Detroit's Metro Times since 1999; photographer for Detroit-based Concentrate Media and Urban Innovation Exchange. His clients include— Rolling Stone, Spin, Billboard, NME, Mojo, Wax Poetics, The Wire, Sub Pop Records, Ghostly Records and Michigan Radio.

Featured Artists: Scott Allen | Misty Lyn Bergeron | Sarah Campbell | Jim Cherewick | Michael Dykehouse | Patrick Elkins | Tadd Mullinix | Zach Nichols | Chris Pottinger | Fred Thomas | Matthew Milia

For more information about Ultimate Stars, go here: http://goo.gl/ZO6mNe
-----------
The 117 Gallery 2016/ 2017 season is supported by Vintage Financial Services LLC.

Catering generously provided by Laura's Catering (http://laurascatering.com/)
name: Ultimate Stars: Opening Reception

description:
Shakespeare is back at Pointless Brewery & Theatre this August!  

After May's sellout performance of MUCH ADRINK ABOUT NOTHING, Ann Arbor's original Shakespeare performance/drinking game is back this time with four performances, over two weekends, with entirely new shows.  Not above taking on low-hanging fruit, we're presenting two of the Bard's most popular and most overdone plays with A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DRINK and THE LAMENTABLE DRINK OF ROMEO & JULIET.  

Shakespeare at Pointless looks to revive a bit of vibrant raucous nature of Shakespeare's early modern theater. Honoring the in-house brewery, the actors will and audience can partake in a drinking game over the course of the plays with specific rules for each play.

All shows are at 8 pm.

Friday, August 19th: The Lamentable DRINK of Romeo & Juliet
Saturday, August 20th: A Midsummer Night's DRINK

Friday, August 26th: A Midsummer Night's DRINK
Saturday, August 27th: The Lamentable DRINK of Romeo & Juliet
name: Shakespeare & Beer: The Lamentable DRINK of Romeo & Juliet

description:

name: Pointless Improv with Listen, Stupid and 50 Shades of Cray Cray
